story: Miracle twins born at  weeks with no chance of survival finally go homeBrother and sister Harley and Harry were born at just  weeks after doctors warned their worried parents they had virtually no chance of surviving- but have now gone homeHarley and Harry have defied the odds and have left hospitalByAntony ThrowerNews ReporterKate Lally:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsMiracle twins given a zero per cent chance of surviving their birth have headed home from hospital with their delighted parents. Harley and Harry were conceived through IVF and were born at just  weeks and five days.Parents Jade and Steve Crane had been warned by doctors it could be a miscarriage as the tiny tots were so young, telling them to “prepare to say goodbye”.But when they were born they showed signs of le so the team burst into action.Now, after  days of intensive care, the brother and sister have been allowed to go home, the Liverpool Echo reports.Former mental health nurse Jade said: Iaposm so proud of my babies - theyaposre little fighters. “Theyaposre doing absolutely amazing. Theyaposre doing all the things that we were told they wouldnapost do - theyaposre crying, theyaposre surviving.  The doctors were saying the babies wouldnapost survive at this gestation. I was still two weeks away from what the UK classes as viable and the babies were given a zero per cent chance of survival. “It was only because I was at a teaching hospital and that the babies were born with signs of le that they chose to intervene medically.”The couple underwent eight cycles of IVF over  years as they tried to start their family, tragically suffering three miscarriages and an ectopic pregnancy before the twins’ arrival.Jade discovered she had an overactive immune system, causing her body to reject the pregnancies before the couple moved from a fertility clinic in Nottingham to one on Harley Street in London.Jade was prescribed several types of medication in order to combat her immune system problems. Jade added: On our eighth cycle of IVF, we had two embryos transferred which both worked and we ended up with boy and girl twins. “I couldnapost let myself believe it, I was so fearful of a miscarriage or something going wrong. I was still in disbelief when we got to  weeks, and I hadnapost even hit my third trimester when I went into labour so we hadnapost bought anything. “The few bits of clothes that I did buy made me think that I better keep the tags on just in case - you just donapost want to let yourself believe. The couple checked in at Queens Medical Hospital in Nottingham on October  when Jade leaked fluid at home for several days at  weeks.  The babies were not considered to be viable and the poor mum believed she would lose her precious twins. She added: The doctor kept saying it was a miscarriage but I said it couldnapost be because I could feel the babies moving. I knew they were ok but was being told they wouldnapost survive at this gestation. It was only because the babies were born with signs of le that they chose to intervene medically. They were alive, moving around, and they cried. Their little cries sounded like a tiny kitten.” The tiny children were finally allowed home on Monday- just two weeks after their initial due date. Steve added: The absolutely stunning doctors, nurses and surgeons have all been part of the making of this moment. “Itaposs hard to say goodbye to them but I hope I never see them again. story: My bridesmaid had my surrogate baby - now our friendship is stronger than everEmma Smuts-Muller married Thomas, , with her best friend Laura Donohoe, , by their side as a bridesmaid. Later, Laura stepped in to be a surrogate mum for EmmaEmma Smuts-Muller and her best friend Laura DonohoeByNatasha Wynarczyk:,  Mar |commentsOver the course of their -year friendship, Emma Smuts-Muller and Laura Donohoe have been there for each other through thick and thin.But now the pair share an even more special bond, after caring Laura stepped in to be a surrogate mother for her best friend - after being bridesmaid for her just months earlier. Emma saw her hopes of conceiving dashed after she was diagnosed with breast cancer in September  and had to undergo treatment which affected her fertility.But thanks to Laura, Emma is now the proud mum of miracle baby Ella and is looking forward to a bright future.“Laura and I have always had an amazing connection with each other since we met at school,” says -year-old Emma, who lives near Birmingham and works as a chief of staff for West Midlands Police. “My husband Thomas and I had realised just how ready we were to have a baby, but after having breast cancer that decision was taken away from us. I will never be able to repay Laura for what she’s done for my family and it’s brought us even closer together.” In May , Emma married Thomas, , with Laura, , by their side as a bridesmaid. Soon after ing from their honeymoon in Lake Como, Emma was delighted to discover that she was pregnant, but tragically miscarried just eight weeks later. The couple were dealt another blow when Emma’s father Terry was diagnosed with leukaemia, then, that September Emma found a mass in her right breast. Scans quickly confirmed the diagnosis of breast cancer.  “I’d had some soreness that I’d initially put down to being pregnant, but when I noticed the changes in my breast I had an instant gut feeling that it was something bad,” Emma recalls. “Thomas and I had been on a massive high after the wedding, and to get pregnant so quickly it felt like everything was going to plan, but to be dealt so many devastating problems one after the other was really dficult for our family. “I just felt myself go into fight mode. I tried to not think too far into the future because it would have been too overwhelming. I knew I had no option but to get on with le.” Emma underwent eight cycles of chemotherapy which started in November . The following April, Emma had a mastectomy which removed her right breast as well as the cm cancerous tumour, then she went on to have two weeks of radiotherapy. Desperate to become a parent, Emma had been told by doctors that the chemotherapy could affect her fertility so she’d been offered IVF before starting her cancer treatment. However, despite successfully freezing  embryos it became clear that it wouldn’t be an option for Emma to carry one of them herself.  Emma says: “Because my breast cancer was linked to hormones, I had oian supression treatment. I was also told I need to take tamoxen - which I am on for  years - to stop the cancer ing. Due to the previous treatment, and the fact tamoxen stops your oies working, I began to go into the menopause. “Doctors also don’t allow you to get pregnant on tamoxen, and due to my age, I would have potentially been too old to carry my own child once I stopped taking the medication.” Emma and Thomas began to explore the possibility of using a surrogate to conceive, then one night Laura, who has two daughters aged seven and  with her husband Rob, came over to their house and told them she would be willing to carry their child. “She just dropped it out there that she would consider being our surrogate, which took us both massively by surprise,” says Emma.“However, due to the coronavirus pandemic the plans were put on hold for a few months, and despite having such a long time to mull it over she didn’t change her mind. I was so grateful to her.”In February , Laura was implanted with one of Emma and Thomas’s embryos. The trio then had a nail-biting two-week wait until Laura could do a pregnancy test.“When she sent the picture of the positive test through, we were so shocked - but really delighted,” says Emma. “We did this part of the fertility treatment with a private clinic but the doctors there told us there was only a % chance of it working due partly to my age and us using a surrogate, so I had prepared for the worst.” On November , Ella was born with Emma by Laura’s side as she went through labour. “Ella was  days overdue, so she did keep us waiting - however, she was definitely worth the wait,” says Emma. “Laura was very clear with her own children that she was just helping myself and Thomas out, and they really understood that. “I never had any worries that Laura would bond with Ella and find it dficult to give her over to us. “We don’t know yet when we will tell Ella how she was born, but it’s such a positive experience however we describe it. Most of all, we want her to understand what a miracle she is.” Now, Emma will have a yearly mammogram and speaks to her oncologist every six weeks to make sure the cancer hasn’t ed. Most of all, she is enjoying being a mum. She adds: “After coming through such a dficult time, Thomas and I finally have something positive to focus on. Laura is an incredible human being for carrying Ella for us.” Breast Cancer Now support and fund research into the condition. story: Ordinary-looking terrace house boasts secret sanctuary under the stairsThe four-bedroom property in Stockport, Greater Manchester, has spacious rooms for humans to enjoy and a special sanctuary underneath the stairs for dogsThe previous home owners had a spoilt dog named Dave Image: PurpleBricksByNia DaltonSpecialist Writer:,  Mar |commentsWhen looking to buy a new home, there are lots of essential amenities people have on their tick list - with multiple bedrooms, a drive and a garden often high up.One thing that isnapost on many peopleaposs lists, but might have reason to be, is a private bedroom for dogs.This unique property in Stockport, Greater Manchester, is offering pet owners a bespoke room specically for their favourite furry members of the family to sit back and relax in private. The four-bedroom home has plenty of space for humans to enjoy, and also a secret sanctuary built under the stairs reserved for pets. to our TeamDogs newsletter for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories.The end-terraced property hit the market at the weekend for £, on estate agency PurpleBricks - and appears to have already been snapped up.It is set over three floors and features two bathrooms, with a handmade gate created to separate the doggy space under the stairs. The previous furry resident, who appears to have been called Dave, was clearly an important member of the family. He has his own orange doggy plaque on the bedroom wall and a personalised pillow on the sofa in the living room. PurpleBricks described the impressive property as: Beautully presented end of terrace town house offering four bedrooms and two bathrooms over three floors. Additional under stairs recess currently used as an enclosed dog bed. The home is located opposite open green communal space with excellent views.  Located within close proximity to shops, well regarded schools and the Manchester Airport Eastern Link Road. Viewing recommended. Property hunters were loving the usage of the small space and commented on social media about the dog-friendly addition. One person said: And it’s even decorated for the dog. Love it. story: Ryanair customer shares genius baggage hack that could save you £ on every flightOn Ryanair flights you dont have a complimentary kg carry on and it needs to be added as an extra, but a TikToker has now shared a genius trick to slash £ from the costTravel fans have praised a passenger who worked out a genius hack for slashing the cost of extra baggage on Ryanair Image: AFP via Getty ImagesBySophie LawTrends EditorRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Mar |comments A Ryanair customer has shared a genius money-saving hack that could help slash £ off your airfare each time you book. When booking with budget airlines, the ticket price isnapost the only cost - with many asking passengers to stump up more cash for everything from snacks to hand luggage.Travellers have now heaped praise on TikToker Cloda Scanlonafter she shared her smart tip for saving a decent sum whenever booking a flight. If you’re headed away on a weekend trip a kg bag isnapost always necessary, but you donapost have a complimentary kg carry when you book with Ryanair and you need to add it as an extra.On Ryanair, the first option when booking allows you to choose your seats and bag requirements, the Daily Record reports.However,you wait it out and select aposvalue fareapos, there is an option later to add luggage.  “If you want a kg bag, it’s a further € per person per journey” - which is the regular fare option. In the video, Cloda explained: “If you want to save between €and €on your next Ryanair flight plus that kg bag, then keep listening. “So I almost paid €for my flights and instead for the exact same flight with the exact same amount of luggage I’m only going to pay € . “So go into the Ryanair app and do your usual - picking your flights, picking your dates. “Instead, go back to the booking page and choose the value fare,” which does not include a kg bag. Then when you click continue, you’re brought to another page where you can manually add the kg back for just €. Cloda said: “That’s instead of what was €per person per journey, so go with a small bag and the value fare, then go through to the end to the booking page” to click your kg option. story: Schoolgirl, , with Downs Syndrome becomes face of big brands - including River IslandA five-year-old girl with Downs Syndrome is championing ersity within the fashion industry and has become the latest face of ious well-known brands, including JD Sports and River IslandLittle Grace is now a bit of a celebrity at schoolByJulia BanimAudience WriterChloe Cawood:,  Mar |comments A five-year-old girl with Downaposs Syndrome has become a model for multiple big brands including JD Sports, CBeebies, and River Island, and her mum is very proud indeed. Young Grace Castle, from Leeds, West Yorkshire, only began modelling two years ago but has already made a name for herself, with her poses and bubbly personality earning her repeat bookings.So far, little Grace has landed deals with some of the best-known clothing brands in the UK, including JD Sports and River Island, and has also modelled in adverts for the likes of CBeebies and Children in Need. Mum, Linda Castle, who runs a café in Garforth, is incredibly proud of her daughteraposs achievements and is thrilled that household name companies are now working to encourage ersity and inclusivity within their advertising. Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. Linda, , said: Itaposs really interesting what we perceive as beauty because weaposre so used to seeing aposunrealapos types of people used to sell clothes. Her friends from support groups love seeing her out there because everybody wants to see somebody who looks like them. Iaposm so proud to see dferent people beginning to be represented and I think the media is taking a huge step. There is still a long way to go to change what we perceive as normal but itaposs refreshing to see brands becoming more integral and real in their approach. Grace, who was diagnosed with Downaposs Syndrome at birth, fortunately, faces no major health complications apart from a small hole in her heart.Linda recalled: When she was born, the staff at the hospital had a bit of a mixed reaction as some people do when you give birth to a child with a disability but it really was one of the happiest days of our lives. When she got to eight months old, we began looking online for support groups to see what was out there for her situation. It was a surprising diagnosis and we were trying to figure out what could be done for her situation. She continued: We came across a group in Scunthorpe which initially did dance and drama for children with learning dficulties but then it became a modelling agency and we wanted to try it for a bit of fun. She was on their books and we went done to London for her first shoot with the clothing company, Boden and she ended up in their catalogue which was amazing. news uk-news uk-weather-forecast-brits-set-"MET Office: UK to expect sunny spells over weekendByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments Brit sun seekers can look forward to warm and dry weather over the coming days which will last into the weekend with temperatures reaching C for parts of the country.There are still cold starts to the day ahead and some patchy rain but a large high pressure sweeping in from the continent means that temperatures will soar with highs in the North West before more unsettled weather s next week. Looking further ahead, it could be a hot spring with weather forecaster Jim Dale reportedly saying that it could get up to C by the middle of April. And bookies are cutting the odds on it being the hottest spring on record. With temperatures on the up, Ladbrokes have slashed odds in half from   to just   on this going down as the hottest spring ever.  Alex Apati of Ladbrokes said: Spring is just around the corner and as things stand weaposre well on course for a record-breaking scorcher,the latest odds are anything to go by.”For this week it will be quite pleasant said BBC Weatheraposs Tomasz Schafernaker with sunshine and dry weather.“In the south where the winds will be light the temperatures will be around the mid-teens. Then Thursday and Friday the high pressure establishes itself across the UK, in fact a big high pressure spreading all the way from Eastern Europe to the edge of Ireland so a lot of settled weather, said Mr Schafernaker. You can see the winds blowing around the high here. Northern and western parts of the country right in the middle of that high where the weather will be sunniest, the winds will be lightest and as a result will have the highest temperatures around C or C.  And that high pressure is expected to persist Friday, Saturday and into Sunday as well although it will be a little breezy at times. Mr Schafernaker continued: Highest temperatures will be C for example Liverpool but on the coast of Cornwall and Devon it could only be about C. Then Saturday into Sunday that high pressure still with us. The winds will change direction a little around the high, they will be coming more out of the south and south east that generally means a lot of dry weather, fairly decent temperatures. UK forecast for the next  days Wet for many today but sunnier on Thursday. Today: Cloudy for most of England, Wales and eastern Scotland rain at times, becoming heavier and more widespread later for central and eastern England. Brighter in northwest UK with some showers, brighter weather edging into other northern and western areas later. Tonight: Rain in eastern England clearing, then many areas turning clear and cold, with patchy frost and some rural mist. Showers in northwest UK easing, but turning wetter and windier later. Thursday: Many areas starting chilly, fine conditions lasting most of Thursday in southern and eastern England. Rain and brisk winds in the northwest spreading to central areas, followed by blustery showers Outlook for Friday to Sunday: Showers in the far north clear early Friday. Some night frost and fog where, but then all areas dry and increasingly sunny. Perhaps cloudier with a few showers Sunday. story: Woman, , diagnosed rare, incurable disease fears it will kill her at any momentAbbey Parker, from Willington, Derby, left doctors stumped when she visited them complaining of pains in her arm, chest and kidneys, only to find out she had an incurable diseaseAbbey Parker, from Derby, was diagnosed with Behcets after complaining to doctors she had a pain in her arm Image: Abbey ParkerByFaith PringJenny MoodySean McPolin:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsA teaching assistant who was diagnosed with a rare and incurable disease after she went to the doctors complaining of arm pains fears it will kill her at any moment.Abbey Parker, from Willington, Derby, was diagnosed with Behcetaposs disease - a condition which inflames blood vessels and tissues - after she began getting pains in her arms, chest and kidneys.The -year-old left doctors stumped medics when she visited the Royal Derby hospital in November last year, only to be diagnosed with heart weakness after multiple tests.She received the shocking news from Dr Robert Berg who she has since thanked for saving her le, Derbyshire Live reports. Speaking about her experience, Abbey said: I got admitted for the kidney infection because I needed an intravenous drip and they kept me in for some more tests. But on one of the rounds of testing there was a bit of miscommunication - but it worked in my favour. The doctors asked meit hurt anywhere and I said it hurt to breathe, but I was referring to my kidney - he thought I meant my chest. They sent for further CT scans on my chest and found the aneurysmon my heart. I was there for  days, my mouth was full of ulcers and I had a lump under my armpit, which turned out to be an aneurysm as well.  Itaposs such a rare disease, normally no one would think about it being that. It was my second kidney infection in such a short period of time so I think that was a bit of a red flag. Boyfriend Jack Bates, , admitted he thinks without the shock diagnosis his girlfriend wouldnapost have made it to Christmas. The electrician has since decided to raise money for Dr Bergaposs research department with a three peaks challenge. He added: Her condition is a lot to take in some days, having to take some time off work to look after her, but it’s scary. The fundraiser is something I’d been wanting to do for a while, to try and raise money for Dr Berg’s research department and Behcetaposs UK as well. Without Dr Berg’s diagnosis in November , Christmas  would have been Abbey’s last. After receiving her diagnosis Abbey was placed on chemotherapy and steroid treatments to prevent the inflammation and will need heart surgery on a mm split which is leaking fluid. The -year-old hopes to be a mum one day and in an attempt to prevent the disease affecting her fertility she is having injections in an attempt to save her eggs. She added: I didn’t realise how serious it was, which was a good thing, but also when they came in to say I had to start chemotherapy and might not be able to have children, it was quite scary. I just thought I had a kidney infection but then they started talking about heart surgery and all this, it’s still strange now.  If I didn’t go in, they thought I was going to die, so it’s a good thing that I got a diagnosis. I’m not religious or anything like that but I do think someone was looking out for me, to go in with a kidney infection and come out with this. I had to leave my job because they said I couldn’t work for  weeks, which is almost a whole year, what was I supposed to do  I think also having an additional barrier of maybe not having children, I meant to be in the prime of my le. She admitted to feeling relieved to know the reason for her symptoms. Abbey added: To finally know what was causing my symptoms, I didn’t want to be in pain all the time, it was such a nice feeling to know that I wasn’t making it up. It was a relief, but it’s a shame that the treatment is so intense. It is for le and it is intense. I struggle to even walk my dog because of my chest pain. I had to get an ambulance last week because I honestly thought my aneurysm had ruptured, and I’ve never been so scared in my le. I really thought that it had ruptured and I was  and dead. It was so scary. Behcetaposs is an incurable form of vasculitis with ying symptoms, and with little research surrounding the illness, it is dficult to receive a diagnosis. story: Real-le Up house owner forced developers to build around home despite £, offerEdith Macefield, , bought her Seattle, Washington home in  and has refused to leave the farmhouse because she did not want the stress - her story warmed the hearts of many in its similarity to the  Disney film UpEdith Macefield refused to move from the -year-old farmhouse despite pleas from from the property developersByMonica CharsleyNews ReporterSamantha MordiHannah Mackenzie Wood:,  Mar |commentsA pensioner who had lived in her home for over  years, turned down a multimillion-pound offer to move - forcing developers to build a mall around it. Edith Macefield became close friends with the property developers during their long negotiations, despite her stubborn stance. The -year-old who bought the home in  with her mother, refused to leave the tiny -year-old farmhouse as she did not want the stress of moving.The property is widely believed to be the inspiration for the Disney film, Up, The Daily Record reports.She even rejected a m [£.] offer for the home in Seattle, Washington, with her story making national headlines back in . Despite the property not being worth much itself, developers first offered the pensioner , [ £,.] before increasing it to  million.  But the le-changing sum didnapost sway Macefieldaposs mind, with her friend stating that although she didnapost object to the development, she didnapost want to have to go through the stress of moving. Barry Martin, who was the construction manager for the major build, became good friends with her and helped her with favours such as making her meals and giving her a lt to appointments. The pair became so close that Macefield left the house to Marin when she passed away in . Unfortunately, Martin had to sell the property when he became unemployed during an economic downturn. However, the pensioner gave him her blessing to sell before she died. He said: “She told me to hold out until I got my price. I sold it for , [£,.], Despite reports that suggest Macefieldaposs story inspired the  movie Up, it was later revealed that the production began years earlier in . story: I named my dog in honour of my late mum - but my family say its disrespectfulThe -year-old woman doesnt understand why her family are so against her dogs name - saying she was only trying to honour her late mums memory when adopting an animal in needShe named her rescue dog Penelope Image: GettyByPaige FreshwaterContent Editor:,  Mar |commentsDeciding on a dogaposs name isnapost always as easy as it sounds as there are so many options to choose from. While some owners seek inspiration from their favourite books, television shows and movies, others opt for a name with a more apospersonal meaningapos behind it.But one dog owner has begun to question whether she was in the wrong after naming her dog in honour of her late mum. Having been branded as disrespectful by her close friends and family, the -year-old has taken to Reddit to explain her unusual situation.to ourTeamDogs newsletterfor your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories. She said: My husband and I recently rescued a new dog and named her Penelope in honour of my mother who passed away last year. My family has said they think that is very weird and disrespectful. They saidI wanted to honour her, I should have taken my motheraposs cat when she passed instead of asking my brother to. Questioning why her dogaposs name has caused such a commotion within her family, the woman has been seeking the opinions of other dog owners. People find comfort in it and your family is a bit weird for being so upset about it. However, others sided with the womanaposs family agreeing it is strange to name a pet after a late loved one. title: mysterious angelic presence captured floating
story: Mysterious angelic presence captured floating above UK town in eerie videoMatthew Gowans, , filmed the eerie UFO as it hung over Prestwick in Ayrshire and said he had eyes on it for a few secondsA man has captured a strange UFO hanging over houses in Ayrshire Image: Credit: Pen News Matthew GowansByLucy SkouldingFreelance writer:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsMysterious footage captures a “humanoid, angelic” presence hanging over the streets of a Scottish city.The eerie stillness of the UFO as it hung over Prestwick, Ayrshire, spurred Matthew Gowans, , to record what he was seeing.“I was starting work for the day and it caught my eye,” he said. “I think,it had been moving, I wouldn’t have paid it much mind. I probably would’ve assumed it was just a balloon or something. “But the fact that it appeared to be completely still was what prompted me to record it.”He continued: “I still have no idea what it could’ve been. “If you use your imagination a bit, it almost appears humanoid, maybe even angelic. I wish I had a phone with a really good zoom to be honest. “I’d be interested to hear what an expert would have to say. “Realistically, it’s probably a trick of the light, but it’s like nothing I’ve ever seen before.” Sharing his footage online, Matthew soon discovered that he wasn’t alone in what he saw. “The most intriguing responses were the couple of people who claimed to have seen something very similar,” he said. “One person said they’d seen it that very same morning where in Scotland.” Mr Gowans kept his eyes on the mysterious presence for a couple of minutes, before looking away for a few seconds to check some of the footage he’d recorded. By the time he’d lted his eyes again, it was gone. “I’m disappointed I didn’t keep an eye on it for longer,” he said. And while some viewers have offered totally ordinary explanations for what he saw, its true nature remains a mystery.  Matthew said: “There were some definitive claims made about it, but the range of those claims proves it’s not cut and dry.“One person said it’s obviously a cloud, one person said it’s obviously a weather balloon, one person said it’s obviously a plane, and so forth.“Personally I don’t think it’s any of those things.” And when it comes to the extraterrestrial, Mr Gowans takes a nuanced view. He said: “Certainly there’s other intelligent le in space. People that believe otherwise sort of baffle me. I mean, the sheer size of the universe… “But, given that sheer size, I think the chances that aliens have made it all the way to Earth – or even been made aware of us – are slim. “There’s so many sightings these days, though, and that NASA investigation a while back was interesting – so many Navy pilots have recounted seemingly credible encounters.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON NasaUFOs" data-immediate"data-immediate" to FREE email alerts with news to brighten your daySubscribeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: People joke theyd rather stay thirsty after seeing odd demand on coffee cupsPeople have been left baffled by the odd demand on a range of disposable coffee cups shared online - with some saying theyd rather stay thirsty than get involvedThe cups sparked the fear of networking in those onlineImage: Getty Images WestendByZahna EklundAudience writer:,  Mar |commentsAs anyone with a corporate job will know, thereaposs nothing more uncomfortable than being forced to socialise with people you barely know as part of a business event.And one woman on Twitter has sparked the fear of networking in thousands of people after she shared a picture of a stack of multi-coloured disposable coffee cups that were seemingly used at a work conference - as they were specically designed to encourage communication between attendees. Jordan Mapes posted the picture of the cups online, where they sat alongside a note that explained how people could choose the cup that was right for them.The cups each had words printed on the front including strategy, articial intelligence, innovation, and leadership, and attendees were told to pick a cup based on what they wanted to talk to others about. Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. Alongside the cups, a note read: Pick a cup based on what you would like to discuss most. This will help everyone to network with like-minded people.Jordan, who posts on Twitter under the username @jordanmapes, then kicked off a debate around the idea of the cups, as she said she would simply not drink coffeeit meant she had to socialise at the same time.Many others took a similar stance, with thousands replying to the tweet to share their distaste for mingling at business meetings - especially when itaposs forced through the use of coffee cups. One person said: I would drink it from my cupped hands rather than go through this torture.  While another added: Nightmares from my days in marketing. And a third said: Strategy is literally my job and even I wouldnapost want this. Others jokingly shared what they would write on their own cups instead, with answers including dinosaurs, Fight Club, and memes. Someone tweeted: This is why I carry a Sharpie with me at all times. Iaposd have to put aposLeave me the f**k aloneapos. As someone  added: Just bring a sharpie with you, cross out whatever it says on your preferred colour of cup, and write aposcatsapos instead. But some were in favour of the idea, as one person pointed out the cups could actually be useful in the right setting, providing everyone involved actually wants to socialise. They said: I actually kinda like the idea, assuming that this is happening at some kind of conference or event where people came specically to discuss this kind of thing, as opposed to the cups being handed out to random people in the street or something. And another agreed, writing: This is dumb but % a genius event idea. Theyaposre always looking for ways to start conversations. Evenitaposs stupid it still works because people can laugh about it and still talk. theyaposre there to protect your walls and paintwork from doors bashing against them and causing dents and scratches. You might also know them as the things that we all used to play with when we were bored that make a satisfying yet annoying sound. But apparently, thereaposs another use that many of us are only just finding out.One TikTok user, who goes by the name @the_artful_odds, has revealed it can also be used as a way to keep the door open.While theyaposre aware this isnapost the main use of the spring, it can be an extra use IF you have a wall guard for the knob. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. They saidyou need your door to stay open, and you have one of these springs on the wall behind it, simply bend the stopper down, open the door fully over the top, then release. The stopper at the end will stop the door from closing. Since being posted, the clip has gone viral, amassing . million views and almost , comments from people who couldnapost believe they were only just finding out about this. One person wrote: How am I learning this today.While another said: What  I’ve never thought of this. A third added: Iaposve learned more from TikTok than any school that Iaposve been to. story: Womans innocent bathroom makeover snap sparks heated hygiene debateA woman took to Facebook to share a picture of her bathroom after she gave it a bit of a makeover with ornaments and photos - but some people were distracted by one detail on the wallThe woman decorated her bathroomByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Mar |commentsA woman has sparked a heated debate online after posting an innocent picture of her bathroom.The anonymous woman took to Facebook to share a snap of her bathroom after giving it a bit of a makeover.“Finally found the perfect art piece for the empty space above our toilet! Waiting for your opinions!” she told members of the Cleaning  Organising Inspiration Australia group. The snap showed her toilet area which had been decorated with a shelf with several ornaments, as well as a picture frame of a dog. But many people were left baffled by one particular detail. title: asteroid spotted two hours before
story: Asteroid spotted two hours before reaching Earth as large fireball seen in skyThe asteroid, which astronomers noticed two hours before it made contact with Earths atmosphere, was just the fth asteroid that had been spotted before potentially hitting the planetThe asteroid careered into view as it was breaking through the Earth’s atmosphere on March  Image: Getty ImagesByAlice PeacockNews Reporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments Astronomers are appealing for footage of an asteroid which was spotted just two hours before its potential collision with Earth.The three-metre asteroid careered into view as it was breaking through the Earth’s atmosphere on March . It was believed the mass may have collided with Earth off the coast of Iceland. According to IFL Science reports, the asteroid was special in that astronomers only noticed it two hours before it made contact with Earth. This makes it only the fth asteroid that had been spotted before potentially hitting the planet. It was currently unclear as to whether the asteroid actually hit the water or broke up in the atmosphere.Local reports from Iceland stated that there was a large fireball overhead, while the near-earth objects coordination centre at theEuropean Space Agency was now appealing for any footage of the asteroid. They note that this was unlikely, due to the remoteness of the location. The sighting was made at a Hungarian observatory by Krisztián Sárneczky, who pointed out a “bright and fast-moving object” in the night sky. The object was named Sar and was initially deemed to have an impact likelihood of less than  percent. However, automatic systems later picked up that Sar in fact had an impact chance of  per cent and would land somewhere near Northern Ireland. Astronomers from all over the world cottoned on and quickly began attempting to monitor the object - no easy feet when it was travelling at . kilometresper second and flying so close to Earth. The object was estimated to have impacted Earth at some point between . and .pm UTC, assuming it made it through the atmosphere before burning up. There was currently no concrete evidence to suggest it did touch down, though there had been indications of a large impact off the coast of Iceland that may be connected. Signals were picked up by both Iceland and Greenland, originating from an impact with an energy release of around  to  kilotons of TNT.  This was considered an indication an asteroid of around  to  metres in diameter had hit the ocean nearby. The asteroid would have broken down and vaporised in parts as it scorched through the atmosphere at that speed. This breakdown was often seen as large flashes of light, often called a fireball, which occurred as friction with eth air breaks the asteroid apart.Anyone who may have spotted the asteroid and have footage, was being asked to submit it to the ESAhere .Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Asteroids" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. Defence has explained why Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has stalled and is failing so far.In the latest intelligence update on the ongoing invasion of Ukraine, they highlighted a number of the problems that Putin’s forces had run into. Challenges like the terrain, and transport issues have severely hampered Moscow’s ability to advance across what is the biggest European country by landmass. On top of that, an inability to secure control of the sky has “drastically limited” their ability to utilise jets and limited their options further. On top of that, the military acumen of the Ukrainian forces and the tactics they have used have exploited Russian weakness and inflicted “heavy losses” on Putin’s invading forces.Want all the latest news and analysis from Ukraine to our World News Bulletin here In a statement released on Twitter, they said: “Russian forces are struggling to overcome the challenges posed by Ukraine’s terrain.“They have remained largely tied to Ukraine’s road network and have demonstrated a reluctance to conduct off-road manoeuvres.“The destruction of bridges by Ukrainian forces has also played a key role in stalling Russia ’s advance.“Russia’s continued failure to gain control of the air has drastically limited their ability to effectively use air manoeuvres, further limiting their options.  “The tactics of the Ukrainian Armed Forces have adeptly exploited Russia’s lack of manoeuvre, frustrating the Russian advance and inflicting heavy losses on invading forces.” This comes as one of Putinaposs closest allies has admitted Russiaaposs invasion of Ukraine have not gone to plan. Viktor Zolotov, chief of Russiaaposs national guard and apart of Putinaposs security council, said progress of the invasion had been slower than expected. He said: I would like to say that yes, not everything is going as fast as we would like, Zolotov said in comments posted on the National Guardaposs website. But we are going towards our goal step by step and victory will be for us.  Zolotov has been at Putinaposs side since before the turn of the century and has spent the last  years in charge of his personal security. His comments, made at a church service led by Orthodox Patriarch Kirill on Sunday, have reflected reports from Western intelligence and mark a departure from official Kremlin lines so far. This comes as Russia’s invasion of Ukraine comes to the end of its third week. In that time, Russia has lost four major generals and nearly a dozen high-ranking officers. It has sustained heavier casualties than Ukraine, and lost more tanks than Germany has in its army.  It was reported, Russia initially planned a ‘lightning invasion’ that would have seen Putin’s forces sweep the country and take Kyiv in a matter of days. However, now the Kremlin finds itself in protracted warfare against Ukraine’s forces and negotiating with the government it hoped to oust. Russia’s invasion has reportedly been plagued with issues such as low morale and supply issues. A number of videos have circulated on social media, showing Russian vehicles running out of fuel. Russia has maintained the invasion is going to plan, but reports from US intelligence officials have said they have been asking China for military equipment since the beginning of the invasion.  After initial failures to conquer Ukraineaposs cities, Russia has turned to relentless shelling and bombing of civilian targets. The deadly invasion has led to thousands of deaths and has led to over three million refugees having fled from their homes since February . The United Nations High Commission for Refugees said, that as of March , ,, Ukrainians had left their homes.  Over half of these, ,,, have entered into Poland, the main destination of refugees so far, but it is not known how many intend to stay here, or move in to other countries. Despite its size, Moldova has taken in , people, the most per capita of any nation. Over , Ukrainians, largely from the country’s eastern regions, have fled into Russia. story: Ten innocent civilians massacred by Russians as they queue for bread in besieged cityFootage shot in besieged Chernihiv, northern Ukraine, shows ten leless bodies after Russian thugs reportedly fired on the group as they waited in line for breadA still from the shocking video widely shared onlineByKieren WilliamsNews ReporterAntony ThrowerNews Reporter:,  Mar |commentsRussian thugs massacred a group of innocent and starving civilians waiting in line for bread in a besieged Ukrainian city, it has been reported.Shocking video from Chernihiv, in the north of Ukraine, showed the horric aftermath as ten people lay dead on the ground.Their leless bodies were heavily blurred in the appalling footage, which also showed an ambulance arriving at the scene.The murders were reported by Hanna Liubakova, a journalist from Belarus, who reported it had happened this morning in one of the “sleeping areas of the city”.The US Embassy in Kyiv later confirmed the carnage and accused Moscow of the crime. They tweeted: “Today, Russian forces shot and killed  people standing in line for bread in Chernihiv.Want all the latest news and analysis from Ukraine to our World News Bulletinhere  “Such horric attacks must stop. We are considering all available options to ensure accountability for any atrocity crimes in Ukraine.” The slayings are the latest in a longline of horric Russian attacks on unarmed Ukrainians, despite the Kremlin promising not to attack civilians. Putinaposs invasion is thought to have taken longer than the Russian president had planned and Moscow appears to have switched to repeat air strikes of residential areas. A maternity and childrenaposs hospital was hit in Mariupol, and hundreds of citizens have been killed since.  Follow the latest updates from Ukraine in our live blog The relentless attacks have also forced more than three million Ukrainians to flee their homes. Earlier today, upsetting drone footage from Ukraine appears to show a man being shot dead by Russian soldiers after he got out of his car with his hands up. It is believed the civilian was killed in front of a woman and child who were still in the car before they were later led away to a wooded area at the side of the road. Last week, -year-old Anastasia Stoluk was gunned down by “drunk Russian troops” in a village near Kyiv, as the Russian atrocities continued. It comes as former world heavyweight champion Vitali Klitschko hit back at Vladimir Putinaposs “bulls*** claimRussiais only targeting military targets inUkraine .Klitschko has been on the front lines as part of his role as the mayor of Kyiv, and has witnessed first hand the destruction in his city. Both he and his brother Wladimir, also a boxing legend, are helping to keep the city safe amid a number of attacks from Russian military. Vitali himself is reported to have picked up arms against Russian soldiers, and slammed Putin again for his comments about only attacking military targets. When asked about it by Channel  reporter Chris Reason in front of another destroyed Kyiv building, Klitschko responded: Bulls***! story: Vet reveals common mistake dog owners make that can cause behaviour issuesThe vet has explained the huge mistake dog owners have been making when welcoming a puppy into their home - and how they can correct the bad behaviours they have mistakenly trained into their petThe vet is urging dog owners to socialise their pets as puppies Image: Getty Images EyeEmByPaige FreshwaterContent Editor:,  Mar |commentsAfter adopting a dog, you find yourself Googling to answer to almost every question that pops into your head. First-time dog owners can become paranoid over the strangest of things - such as whether their has taken too many or too few toilet trips that day. But according to a vet, most owners have been making a huge mistake with their dogs, which could be the reason for their training or behavioural issues.Taking to Reddit, one vet has explained the common mistake owners make when welcoming a new puppy into their home. to our TeamDogs newsletter for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories. They said: Not letting your dogs around other dogs until they have all their vaccines.Their socialisation window closes about  weeks, meaning it is pretty much closedyou wait until  weeks. This causes a lot of dogs to go nuts and freak out whenever they see something they didnapost see during that period. While urging owners to socialise their new puppies in a safe environments, they warned them against taking their dog to a park or open space commonly used by dog walkers. They need to be around other dogs and other people in controlled situations - puppy socialisation classes, friends houses, they added. Make sure the dogs they are around are healthy, vaccinated, and good with puppies and let them have positive experiences with other dogs and people. Obviously never get behind on their vaccines while youaposre doing this. To accustom a puppy to dferent people and aposunknownapos objects, the vet says owners should introduce them to their tall friends, friends of dferent races and friends with beards, hats and sunglasses.  They added: Pull out the broom, an umbrella, an iron board while giving them treats and having fun the whole time. Try to let them walk on slick floors, bricks and carpet so they wonapost have fears of those things - and always happy. Every happy, positive interaction with something makes them less afraid. Every lack of exposure, or negative interaction, makes them more afraid. Your dog is your friend, not your slave. Your goal is not to make him do exactly whatever you want no matter what. Itaposs to make him have good manners, but also let him have his own preferences, too. Youaposre not training him like heaposs in the circus to do a bunch of stuff for your amusement. Youaposre teaching him how to move safely in the world, which means not doing something - biting, urinating in the house, jumping uncontrollably - that will be a threat to his le some day.More dogs are surrendered and euthanized for behaviour reasons than any other reason. When asked how an owner can socialise an older dog who missed this step during their puppyhood, the vet advised the aposclassical conditioningapos technique. The vet added: Most training relies on operant conditioning, which is the aposwhen you do desired action X, I give you a rewardapos. Classical conditioning does not rely on a given action or cue, so itaposs less intuitive. Youaposll often hear lies like aposIf theyaposre scared, donapost give them a treat, youaposll reward the fear.apos This is not true, especially when it comes to emotional responses in dogs. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowIt is good that Argyll and Bute Council has tightened up its procedures so that elected councillors are kept #in the loop# over signicant decisions affecting their wards.Councillor Philand is perfectly entitled to be frustrated not to have been included, along with his fellow Mid Argyll members, in the development of a plan to improve the Crinan Canal corridor # until a meeting to decide on its removal from the council-wide #Levelling Up# bid.Just why it wasn#t ready is not clear, but councillors should have been involved.The only saving grace is that the canal corridor regeneration bid will go forward as part of the Rural Growth Deal, part-funded by the UK and Scottish governments along with a contribution from Argyll and Bute Council.Let#s hope this goes to plan and the Rural Growth Deal lives up to its aspirations and delivers real progress for the region.That aside, there are already signs of improvement in Mid Argyll and Tarbert, with recent news of some cash for Tarbert Lochgilphead front green making progress and the Conservation Area Regeneration Scheme coming soon planned Ardrishaig improvements and other projects including the MACPool upgrade and the refurbishment of Kilmartin Museum.

title: back to nature at inveraray history society
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowInveraray History Society took a walk on the wild side at its latest meeting as Argyll Estates# head stalker set his sights on an entertaining evening.Tom Kirsop provided society members with an informative and imaginative talk at their February gathering, covering his work and experiences on the local estate.Growing up in Clydebank, Tom had always had an interest in animals and moved to Argyll as a forest ranger in Dalmally.Since starting to work with Argyll Estates, which he thoroughly enjoys, Tom has been able to develop his work with animals in many dferent ways.In Queen Victoria’s time the current ,-acre estate was on an even bigger scale and has witnessed a huge increase in the number of deer since then.This has been due to the lack of any natural predators and, with further planting of trees since the s, the deer have had more protective covering.Modern inventions such as drones and the use of argocats, have made it easier for people working on estates to estimate numbers of deer more accurately and to be able to meet the necessary annual targets of keeping the deer population to manageable levels.Working on the estate also involves a range of other projects, such as collecting data on golden eagles, barn owls, making fishing available at the Glen Shira dam and taking clients out stalking.More recently Tom has started up West Highland Wildle Tours to give people of all ages a real insight into the wildle and beautul scenery on our doorstep.For the society#s March meeting, Ken MacTaggart will give a presentation about #The Medieval Pilgrim Way to Loch Awe#.The venue will be Inveraray church hall on Tuesday March , starting at .pm.Everyone is welcome. Please follow the Inveraray and District History Society on Facebook for our latest news.

story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowWhatever the rights and wrongs of Putin#s invasion of Ukraine, which has been shocking to witness from afar, one thing has shone through.The courage of the Ukranian people should serve as inspiration to each of us to stand against tyranny, in all its forms.As ever when the powerful invoke conflict, it#s the not-so-powerful and less wealthy who bear the brunt. The sight of the Ukranian people desperately seeking safety in neighbouring countries evokes scenes in Europe from the Second World War, as Hitler#s forces advanced, and later refugee crises sparked by the more recent Balkan conflict.As reported in this edition the women, children and elderly are heading in one direction # while the young men, and no doubt plenty of women too, are going the opposite way to defend their country from Putin.In the midst of such suffering and bravery, it is heartening to hear of so many Argyll folk joining a huge Europe-wide effort to help those forced to flee their homes.We would encourage our readers to support this cause in whatever way you can. No matter what happens next, the need for aid is going to be there for a long time to come.

title: science matters another unwelcome invader 2
story: Dorothy H CrawfordUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowMost of us are active by day and rest by night, but within these confines there are several possibilities ranging from larksto owls .These preferences, called chronotypes, have a genetic basis that controls one#s biological clock, but this can be modied by ious factors such as light exposure, age and lestyle.However, when the genetic and environmental cues are not aligned a chronic condition known as #social jetlag# may ensue.This problem is exacerbated during adolescence when chronotypes become increasingly delayed, but schools start early in the morning.This can cause sleep loss that may lead to major health and psychological problems and also affect academic performance.In a recent study scientists examined how the interaction between chronotype and school start time influenced inidual academic performance* by taking advantage of a high school system where  students had been randomly assigned to lessons in the morning , afternoonor evening .This enabled the unbiased testing of the effect of chronology and school schedules on academic performance in adolescents aged - years and - years.The results showed that among the early morning group, very few students got adequate sleep.The larksoutperformed owlsin all school subjects and this effect, which increased as students progressed through the school, was most extreme in maths.This outcome, however, was not evident in those having afternoon schooling, and the situation almost reversed in those receiving evening schooling, where students with later chronotypes performed slightly better in languages than the early chronotypes in the same group.Clearly academic performance is influenced by biological iation in daily rhythms, to an extent that has previously been underestimated.The study authors, while conceding that it is impractical to attempt to fully align school timetables to inidual chronotypes, suggest that it may be possible to, for example, progressively delay school start times during adolescence.* Goldin et al.  https:doi.org . s---.

your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowArgyll and Bute teams travelled to Fort William on February  for the Camanachd Association National Primary Schools shinty festival finals.The competition was back after a y layoff and gave teams from across Scotland a chance to compete against each other.Tighnabruaich, Inveraray and Rockfield primary schools headed to the Nevis Centre for the P- age group while at P-, Rockfield and a combined Dalmally and Inveraray team played their matches at Lochaber High School.Les Kinvig, development officer for the West region, said he was delighted to see teams from his area competing at this level and that it was a great experience for the slightly inexperienced players who would hopefully benefit from it.Winners on the day both came from Inverness, with Muirtown Primary School taking the P- final and Bun-sgoil Gaidhlig Inbhir Nis lting the P- trophy.Speaking after the tournament, Mr Kinvig highlighted the need for indoor facilities in Argyll and Bute to enable youngsters from his area to compete at this level.#We need facilities that are big enough to train and play competitive shinty in,# he said.#Many are having to make do with very small gym halls or community centres that are not big enough.#The teams and I appreciate what is available, but to progress shinty in the region we must try to find a solution for better facilities to accommodate indoor wintertime shinty.#Mr Kinvig added he would be working with Argyll and Bute Council and Live Argyll to seethere is a way to increase opportunities.PIC:Action from Inveraray v Muirton, the eventual winners, in the p  competition. title: in columbas footsteps without cuban heels
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowA TV series will feature Mid Argyll as it follows seven celebrities on a pilgrimage through Ireland, Northern Ireland and Scotland.#Pilgrimage# follows the celebs # of dferent faiths and none # for  days as they follow in the footsteps of Saint Columba, seeking out his legacy as a key figure in early British Christianity, helping spread the faith from Ireland to Scotland and beyond.Along the way Will Bayley, Scarlett Moffat, Monty Panesar, Louisa Clein, Laurence Lewellyn-Bowen, Shazia Mirza and Nick Hewer enjoyed the hospitality of the people of Knapdale.They arrived in Achahoish on September  last year, having set off from Northern Ireland the previous day by boat.Tired and weary, the pilgrims were welcomed into South Knapdale Parish Church at Achahoish, where they met with some of the congregation and shared a meal.South Knapdale Parish Church Minister Reverend David Carruthers explained: #The programme#s producers # and the visitors # had caught wind of the fact that the church in Achahoish has been used previously by pilgrim groups passing through.#The Presbytery of Argyll#s youth workers have previously arranged pilgrim walks under the banner of the Columba Experience and the church at Achahoish was used for accommodation on two successive years.#After their meal at Achahoish, the group started to share with one another something of their backgrounds, beliefs and faiths whilst the TV cameras rolled.After three hours of fascinating chat, the locals went home and the travellers bedded down on the church floors in their sleeping bags.Next day the pilgrims headed northwards via Columba#s Cave near Ellary, where Father Simon MacKenzie of Christchurch in Lochgilphead conducted a short act of worship.The celebrity pilgrims began their journey in Donegal before travelling to Argyll. From Knapdale, they headed up the west coast, sailing to Lewis and Harris before arriving at their final destination, Iona.Covering almost , miles in the series, they visit places of worship, from pagan stones to an early Christian cave and a contemporary mosque and Sikh temple. The journey tests the pilgrims not just spiritually, but physically too.TV celeb and comedian Scarlett Moffatt, , said: #At school, I spent a lot of time just reading books and on my own and so that’s how I got into faith really. It just felt calming. There’s almost a stigma attached to sort of being religious.#Whenever I would tell my friends, they’d laugh and I’d be like, #why is that funny # I believe in God, there has to be something that started all this.#I would describe myself as Christian, but not a strict Christian. I don’t go to church, but I definitely believe and religion to me is security.#She added: #In my head somebody on a pilgrimage is in a loin cloth and they have really long hair#and they look a bit dehydrated like they need a good moisturiser mask.#I’m doing the pilgrimage as I want to know what my religion is. I want to be able to answer that question with confidence.#TV personality and interior designer Laurence Lewellyn-Bowen describes himself as a #non-conforming pagan#. The -year-old explained: #I think pilgrimage is about clearing out your mental closet by physical exertion and by spiritual conversation with yourself or,you believe it, then conversation with your God.#I know I come across as all sort of flouncy and floppy and rather cavalier, but I am capable of existing in the real world.#However, I don’t think I’ve walked so far not wearing Cuban heels.#Pilgrimage: The Road to the Scottish Isles will be screened on BBC Two and iPlayer in the spring with three one-hour-long episodes, and is a CTVC production.

title: shinty round up saturday march 5 2
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowThe new shinty season got up and running with goals galore across the country on Saturday March .Fort William  Kyles Athletic Kyles Athletic came from two goals down to earn a - title: thought for the week march 11 2022
story: Hannah OHanlonUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Who am I  What am I  Where am I  How am I  – questions of identity and some of the questions I was left asking when I left a recent meeting.That meeting was part of a world-wide movement – a movement that calls the peoples of the world to pray.Similar questions of identity were raised when I was asked to write ‘a piece’ for this newspaper. The questions weren’t so much about me but you – who are you  What are you  Where are you  And how are you I can answer the questions about ‘me’ relatively easily, knowing that others might disagree. But I cannot so easily answer such questions about you for I don’t really know who reads this column.Identity, human identity, all of us wrestle with questions of identity – from the inidual to a community to a nation or a race.Who are the Scots  Who are the Ukrainians  Who are the Russians  Where do you come from The answers are never as simple as we think they might be or would like them to be.Humanity is such a erse and multi-faceted part of creation.In recent weeks, many have tried to understand why the world finds itself on the potential tipping point of another large-scale war.In part, it is to do with identity – a simplication, I know – and a greed for power, land and wealth.Doomsters will shake their heads and wring their hands in despair, offering little hope.Politicians will talk and negotiate and may God bless them as they do!What will you do Your response will reflect something of your identity.Will you identy with a world-wide movement and pray for the well-being of the world

title: leader blasts council pothole policy
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowArgyll and Bute Council’s leader has claimed that the authority is not #getting it right first time# when it comes to pothole repairs # and branded short-term repairs #a waste of money#.Kintyre and the Islands Liberal Democrat Councillor Robin Currie made the comments after another councillor raised concerns about similar situations on the Cowal peninsula.That was despite a report which claimed that the council had a  per cent record in repairing potholes within  hours in the last three months of .Cowal Liberal Democrat Councillor Alan Reid queried the quality of repairs which were carried out after concerns were expressed by constituents.The discussion took place at a virtual meeting of the council’s environment, development and infrastructure committee on March .Councillor Reid said: #That [the reported  per cent record] is very good, but I want to ask about follow-up inspections.#At the last meeting of Colintraive and Glendaruel Community Council, they told me that potholes had been filled in, but in practically no time at all, the tar came out and the potholes were not sealed properly.#It is something that has been raised time and time again over my five years with the council. What quality control do we have in place here, and do we record the success rate of pothole packing  And what are we going to do to improve the success rate #Jim Smith, the council’s head of amenity services, replied: #We aim to do it right first time for repairs, but the first priority is ensuring that the route is fit for purpose, so we have to do emergency repairs from time to time.#In winter, when everything is wet and you have sub-zero temperatures, there are challenges in carrying out repairs. It is also recommended that you don’t lay anything when the temperature is less than five degrees.#If you have cold conditions, it may be that sometimes you have to do emergency repairs. We also use a range of materials and will use materials which will do a quick job and make things safe but are not a permanent fix.He added that #there will be some repairs lasting only a short period, but most are done on a right-first-time basis#.Councillor Currie said: #I certainly agree with Councillor Reid. I had a chat with Jim and Kirsty [Flanagan, executive director] just the other day, and I am going to be blunt # I don’t think we are getting it right first time.#I can give an example more or less outside my house. It has been repaired four times in the last year and a half, and that is not an isolated example.#To me, it is happening all the time, and that is a complete waste of money. We should be getting it right first time and this needs to be looked at.#PIC:Argyll and Bute Council leader Robin Currie. no_aelectionCurrieEmergency repairs are sometimes needed to Argyll potholes, said Jim Smith, the council’s head of amenity services. _croadcondition
