story: Mid and East Antrim Borough Council is delighted to be working in partnership with Well North Enterprisesand Professor Brian Cox CBE to bring the prestigious Science Summer School to Northern Ireland in November  at The Braid Arts Centre, Ballymena.Through collaboration with headline sponsor Ryobi Aluminium Casting and key sponsors Almac Group, IPC Mouldings, Michelin Development, Northern Regional College, Randox Laboratories and Terumo Blood and Cell Technologies the event will aim to inspire young people to become the next generation of scientists with an inspirational programme that mixes the best of STEAMthrough a series of TED-style talks, seminars, discussions and hands-on workshops.The Science Summer School is not a stand-alone event but is a catalyst for a collaborative vision for the borough to nurture future talent and as part of the event we are asking pupils to ‘Activate your Curiosity’ by creating an original t-shirt design that reflects one of three themes: Activate your Curiosity First Attempts or The Universe.There are fantastic prizes on offer - the winning t-shirt will be printed and the designer will have the opportunity to meet Professor Brian Cox CBE in November .The best ideas will also be included in the Gallery of First Attempts exhibition in the Mid-Antrim Museum at The Braid in conjunction with this exciting event.The competition is open to all schools in the borough from Key Stage  through to Key Stage  and to enter students must attend a school in the Mid and East Antrim Borough Council area. The closing date for entries is pm, Friday  May .To find out further information and to download competition entry forms please visit: www.midandeastantrim.gov.uk SSSCompetition or contact: E: amply@midandeastantrim.gov.uk T:

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220316newsflybe set to return to the skies from belfast
story: Flybe is making ato Belfast, it has been announced. Headquartered in Birmingham, George Best Belfast City Airport is to become its second main base of operations. And it is reported that flights to a number of destinations are set to go on sale next week. Flybe CEO, Dave Pflieger, said: “Next week is going to be an exciting time for customers and communities that have been waiting to hear from us about low fares, new routes, and new destinations—all of which are being timed to coincide with the restart of the economy and ato normality after two dficult years for all. “As you’ve heard, our team has been working hard for over a year and a half to bring customers a new airline that people will love, and we are particularly excited to be flying to Belfast City Airport and serving Northern Ireland. “Once we start flying from Birmingham, Belfast, and many other cities in the UK and EU, we are confident that a new and improved Flybe will provide customers with great value, more choices, and the opportunity to quickly and more conveniently visit loved ones, go on holiday, and more easily visit customers or attend important meetings. “Given that goal, Flybe hopes to do its part to help communities across the country bounce back from the dramatic impact of the global pandemic.”

title: is northern ireland on track to reach its climate change targets
story: The road to net zero is littered with obstacles as political parties lock horns over a ban on smoky coal and other environmental issues. In the absence of an Executive, some ambitions have been thwartedExpandExpandPreviousNext" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseA protester at Stormont as the Climate Bill was being discussed. Credit: Liam McBurneyPeople in fancy dress protest about the state of the notorious Mobuoy dump on the outskirts of Londonderry FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueA protester at Stormont as the Climate Bill was being discussed. Credit: Liam McBurneyGarrett HarganTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailProgress on climate legislation has been slow and arduous in Northern Ireland, in part due to its dependence on agriculture, an industry responsible for % of greenhouse gas emissions.A bill has now been passed but does it go far enough and what targets does Northern Ireland need to meet in order to secure real change that would benefit both the environment and public health Climate change billNorthern Ireland has finally brought itself in line with every other country in Western Europe by approving its own climate change legislation.Late progress was made in this Assembly mandate however there was some criticism that Northern Ireland remains an exception in delivering net-zero ambitions.MLAs passed an amendment tabled by Minister Edwin Poots which caps the target for methane emissions.The Minister argued that cutting cattle herds was not an option, particularly with an escalating crisis in Ukraine which could impact food supplies in Northern Ireland.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up His amendment sets a separate target for methane as part of wider ambitions for net zero emissions by . It means that methane emissions for  are not required to be more than % lower than the  baseline. The law now needs to be implemented.Read MoreAssembly passes climate Bill committing Northern Ireland to net zero by Tree coverageNorthern Ireland ranks badly as one of the least-wooded regions in Europe, with just % woodland cover compared with the European average of %. In addition, almost % of our woodland is in the form of recent coner plantations.The Woodland Trust said Northern Ireland needs to signicantly increase tree plantingit is to help towards a UK woodland target.The conservation charity previously published its Emergency Tree Plan. The plan sets out how the UK can rapidly increase tree cover to help reach net zero carbon emissions and tackle the declines in wildle.Northern Ireland would need to plant , hectares of trees a year to hit an existing target of % cover by . To contribute to this, the Forests For our Future Programme announced by Mr Poots in March  set targets to create , hectares of new woodland by , which falls well short of those recommended by the Woodland Trust.The Department for Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairshas a woodland expansion target  hectares for  .Ammonia emissionsAmmonia is an air pollutant largely emitted from agriculture and has a damaging impact on bioersity, including sensitive habitats, as well as human health. It is produced by many common farming activities, such as the housing of livestock, the storage and spreading of manure and slurries, and the application of fertiliser.An Audit Office report from February found that most areas of Northern Ireland, including designated sites and other priority habitats, are affected by high levels of nitrogen being deposited on land and into water surfaces.The levels in most areas are signicantly above what is considered their “critical load”, the concentration of nitrogen at which signicant ecological damage occurs. Northern Ireland is responsible for % of UK ammonia emissions, despite only having % of its population and % of its land area, and is the only region of the UK where ammonia levels have not been decreasing.“Failure to address the increasing level of ammonia emissions also has the potential to contribute to serious, long-term harm to the environment and human health,” the report concluded.Mr Poots has conceded that a failure to publish an Ammonia Reduction Strategywill be a regret when he leaves office and it is one that has left the department vulnerable to legal challenge. However, he stresses that he wants to publish a strategy before leaving office.Independent Environmental Protection AgencyUnder an outline programme for government in the New Decade, New Approach, a number of coordinated measures to reverse climate change were laid out.They included an Independent Environmental Protection Agencyto oversee targets that would be set as part of climate change legislation.Mr Poots is opposed to the establishment of an IEPA, believing it to be unnecessary bureaucracy. However, he has proposed setting up an office of environmental protection to do similar independent work.Conservation Management PlansNorthern Ireland is home to important nature and wildle, of both national and international importance, which are a key part of the Northern Ireland landscape, providing a wide range of goods and services to society and helping to deal with climate change.The UK faced formal infringement proceedings by the European Commission because of the failure to have in place Conservation Management Plansfor its European sites.There are  special areas of conservation and  special protection areas in Northern Ireland. Strangford Lough and Rathlin Island were reported to the commission as having a CMP in place.That leaves  sites without such plans in Northern Ireland.At the time of the infraction proceedings it was reported to the Commission Rathlin Island and Strangford Lough had Conservation Management Plansin place.The Commission took the view that developing CMPs for each of the remaining SACs would signicantly contribute to addressing the alleged failings to comply with the obligations under the Habitats Directive.DAERA subsequently embarked on a signicant programme of work to develop such CMPs to date draft CMPs have been developed for  of the SAC sites, with the intention to have draft plans for all SACs completed by December .Clear AirAir pollution is the top environmental risk to human health in the UK, and the fourth greatest threat to public health after cancer, heart disease and obesity.The Clean Air Strategy, published in January  by the UK Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs , sets out a number of objectives to improve air quality across the UK.Additionally, DAERA issued a Clean Air Strategy for Northern Ireland Discussion Document for public consideration in November . The period of public discussion closed in early .This strategy aims to build on existing improvements within Northern Ireland and seeks to tackle important cross-Departmental issues relating to transport, energy, agriculture, industry, local air quality management, and communications.An air quality strategy was anticipated but has not been published. Minister Poots says that recommendations await the next office holder.Mobuoy super dumpAt public meetings, government officials have been repeatedly challenged to urgently deal with an estimated one million cubic metres of waste at the Mobuoy “super dump” on the outskirts of Derry. The River Faughan which forms the western boundary of the site supplies the city with % of its drinking water.Ongoing legal action has been blamed for delaying remediation work at the site. That trial is due to commence next month.The clean-up cost at Mobuoy has been estimated at a minimum of £ million — and potentially as much as £ million.NI Water and DAERA have always assured the public that chemicals present in drinking water are at safe levels. However, campaigners contend there are “no safe levels” of arsenic or manganese as exposure to such chemicals can have a long-term damaging effect on the brain.It is expected that based on successful approval of a business case, a remediation contractor will be appointed by late .Ban on petroleum licensingIn a somewhat unexpected move, the DUP Economy Minister, Gordon Lyons, announced that he would support a ban on fracking and onshore petroleum licensing activity in Northern Ireland.Fracking is broadly banned across the UK and Ireland. In England, the Government told the industry it would not agree to any future fracking “until compelling new evidence is provided” that it was safe.Two petroleum licensing applications in NI relate to Fermanagh, where a company called Tamboran Resources UK applied for a licence in .A separate application from EHA Exploration takes in five council areas: Belfast, Antrim and Newtownabbey, Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon, Lisburn and Castlereagh, and Mid Ulster.However, Sinn Fein said it is “bitterly disappointing” that as a result of the DUP collapsing the Executive, that ban cannot now be brought forward.Water pollutionA recent ‘Water Framework Directive Statistics Report’ determined that none of Northern Ireland’s  rivers, lakes and coastal waters achieved a “good overall status” rating for water quality.Environmentalists have argued that minimal fines handed down for water pollution do not act as an appropriate deterrent for repeat offenders.Figures obtained by Green Party MLA Rachel Woods showed that more than seven million tonnes of raw sewage is being dumped into Northern Ireland’s seas and rivers every year.NI Water requires investment of around £bn in water and wastewater services over a six year period, the Utility Regulator said in May. This financial year the DfI Minister allocated a combined budget £m to NI Water for  .Coal banSmoky coal is one of the worst causes of air pollution. It has been reported that approximately , premature deaths have been averted in Dublin since the introduction of a coal ban back in . In the past, DUP MP Sammy Wilson strongly opposed proposals saying that low-income households who use cheap coal would be adversely affected as smokeless coal costs more.In response, then Environment Minister Mark H Durkan said: “It is great to hear Saint Sammy, defender of the disadvantaged — I do not know what happened to Sammy, the champion of the Tory cuts — make all these arguments on behalf of those suffering fuel poverty.“There is not a word about the big business interests of those in the coal business or, indeed, the interests of Larne port in his own constituency.”DUP MLA Michelle McIlveen, who was DAERA Minister before the Assembly collapsed, also said it was not her intention to ban smoky coal in the North.Now, Mr Poots, says he has no intention of banning coal because people MaddenTwitterEmailMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailThe dire state of the planning system has been laid bare after it emerged the average waiting time for a decision on regionally signicant applications is almost three-and-a-half years.Current major applications stuck in the pipeline include a proposed gold mine in Co Tyrone and the Arc incinerator project in Co Antrim.Data from the Department for Infrastructureindicates the average processing time for such applications in the period April  to September  was . weeks.An Audit Office report earlier this month warned the planning system is not fit for purpose and risks causing economic damage.A recent review of the  Planning Act by DfI recommended several changes, including: reviewing the consultation requirements in plan-making improving the quality of planning applications submitted and increasing the use of digital technology.DUP MLA Diane Dodds said: “The Infrastructure Minister’s review of the Planning Act was completely ineffective and the Audit Office’s recent report was absolutely damning in its assessment of the planning system here.“That report highlighted clearly how it is failing to deliver for the economy, communities or the environment.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up “These delays are costing jobs and hampering the prosperity of Northern Ireland. Our direct competitors in the Republic of Ireland are dealing with such signicant applications much more efficiently. This is a major consideration for companies deciding where to invest.”Alliance MLA Andrew Muir said the delays point to a “systemic problem” at the heart of DfI, which “ought to be leading as a role model in planning matters, but instead is more like a black hole where key planning applications disappear for determination to be delayed for years”.“Nothing less than radical reform is needed to ensure the voices of communities are better heard and applications not left sitting stuck in the system without a decision to reject or approve,” he added.DfI said: “The department is working closely with key stakeholders in a number of ways to improve processes and increase the efficiency of the planning system to ensure that planning applications are processed in a timely manner. “A review of the implementation of the Planning Act has been completed. In addition, the department, as part of a collaborative project with  councils, will be delivering a new planning IT system next year which will improve the submission and processing of planning applications.“A planning engagement partnership has also been established to look at how to enhance the quality and depth of community engagement in the planning process at both the regional and local planning levels.“It is hoped that the collective improvements delivered from this work will improve processes and increase the efficiency of the planning system across the board.”Related topicsAndrew title: mla seeks to investigate recent surge in fuel prices amid kilroot power station confusion
story: The UKs competition regulator should look at what happened as oil prices surged here last week, Stormonts Economy Committee has heard.MLA John O#Dowd wants the committee to write to the Competition and Markets Authority and ask it to investigate the surge in petrol, diesel and home heating oil.The Sinn Fein MLA said he had information that suggested normal practises that happened when oil is imported and sold may not have happened over a period during which the price surged. He did not want to elaborate further at this point.He asked the committee to write a letter as a body to add heft to the request for the competition regulator to investigate. He told the committee he wanted to make sure consumers are getting value for money.The committee also heard demands for answers from government departments on what exactly the policy is on the importation of Russian coal amid confusion over its use by Kilroot Power Station.The economy committee was responding to the revelations in the Belfast , that the power station wants to switch to other suppliers but cannot do so because of licensing requirements imposed by Stormont.East Antrim MLA Stewart Dickson, whose constituency includes the facility, said he was very disappointed to hear the Department for the Economy had no comment and is passing the buck to the Department of Agriculture.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up They have to get out of their silos and do their job, the Alliance Party representative said.Mr Dickson said he realised the station is required to burn low sulphur coal but added Russia is not the only supplier. It might be the cheapest but it is not the only one.The MLA added the ships carrying Russian coal and arriving in Belfast appear to be operating under flags of convenience and noted there was a lack of clarity on this situation from the UK government.There is a lack of clarity from the UK government… these ships are not welcome but the reality is work needs to be done to work out all the consequences, the MLA argued.Mr Dickson noted there may be contractual issues surrounding the purchase and delivery of the coal.But he added other EU nations can provide the cleaner coal, though it will be more expensive due to its safety and working standards compared to Russia.!forfort[r].style.e.data["datawrapper-height"][a]+"px"He described standards in Russian mines as appalling and rock bottom, prompting DUP MLA Keith Buchanan to note thatit is wrong to buy Russian coal now, it should have been wrong six weeks ago, three months ago.The SDLP#s Matthew O#Toole wants the committee to seek clarity from the relevant government departments, including what instructions they are receiving from the UK government given energy supplies are not subject to sanctions.Mike Nesbitt, of the Ulster Unionists, also wants answers from Belfast Harbour, particularly as members of Belfast City Council sit on Board of Commissioners.Related topicsUkraineThe Executive OfficeMore On title: ni retail consortiums aodhan connolly bristling with joy as he wins irish beard of the year once again
story: Aodhán Connolly FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueAodhán ConnollyMark BainTwitterEmailMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailFor the second year in a row, Northern Ireland Retail Consortium director Aodhan Connolly has claimed the title of Irish Beard of the Year.Announced for St Patrick’s Day, the online vote saw Aodhan take the honour, but it was a close shave as he beat off competition from Health Minister Robin Swann.“You could blow me down with a feather,” he said. “I’d like to thank my parents for the genes!”One of the most instantly recognisable faces in Northern Ireland, Aodhan said that despite his run of success, he had no plans to send the beard into retirement.“I’ve had a beard on and off since I was , once I got through the fluff stage,” he added. “I suppose it’s just become part of who I am. My god-daughter Lily likes to call me uncle Hagrid.“I do get askedI would like to shave it off for charity, but that’s never going to happen. I know what I look like underneath it - bowling ball comes to mind! No, it’s staying, I’ll stick to doing the half-marathons for charity.“Anyway, my son Thomas says it’s the only thing that’s cool about me. He’s  and anything a -year-old says is cool about his old man has to be kept. He likes the beard, though not the public profile so much.”Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up The voting, ran by the Beard Liberation Front, took place over two preliminary rounds earlier this month, with the final nominations lined up for an online ‘beard-off’ between March -.Those in the final selection included former Open golf championship winner Shane Lowry, Health Minister Robin Swann, broadcaster William Crawley, Maynooth University professor Peter Coles and Matthew O’Toole of the SDLP.“I would have loved to see Robin Swann get some recognition for all his hard work over these past two years,” said Aodhan, congratulating his fellow competitors on their nominations.Success on the beard stage doesn’t come easy, though. For Aodhan, keeping it trim is a daily routine of essential oils and conditioner.He said: “It gets the works every day. You suffer for the success. It’s a daily shampoo, conditioner, oil and balm experience to keep it up to scratch.“It always give people something to talk about. It has a le of its own and has given me a fair few nicknames over the years. I remember being introduced at an academic event recently as the Brian Blessed of Brexit. That was quite an honour.”It might be an evening toasting his beard recognitions with a Guinness, but Aodhan said he won’t let the success go to his head.“There won’t be anything crazy like dying it green for St Patrick’s Day. It’s had a few makeover over the years. It was a cheesy goatee for a while, I’m sure it won#t mind me mentioning that, so it’s had an interesting and eventful le.”Previous winners of The Beard Liberation Front, the informal network of beard wearers, include SDLP leader Colum Eastwood, who didn’t make the cut for the final this year.Keith Flett of the Beard Liberation Front said: “The poll is specically about the impact the beard of an inidual has made in Irish public le and no other factor.“Aodhan Connolly is to be congratulated on being the first person to win consecutive titles. Clearly his beard is making a positive impact in the public eye.”Most ReadIncrease of ‘sexual shenanigans’ in Northern Ireland forestA sit-in fish supper could climb to £ in Belfast, says restaurant Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownNorthern IrelandNews HeadlinesBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremium Northern Ireland power station wants to ditch Russian coal — but Stormont says noSam McBrideTwitterEmailMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailOne of Northern Ireland’s main power stations wants to stop buying Russian coal — but is forced to do so by Stormont’s licence requirements.A huge shipment of Russian coal arrived in Belfast Harbour at the weekend using a vessel registered in the Marshall Islands to transport the consignment to Belfast Harbour, meaning it was landed without breaking the UK’s sanctions regime.On Tuesday much of the shipment was still visible in the harbour. Kilroot power station said that shipment was not for it, and it last brought in Russian coal on th February. The power station, which dominates the northern shoreline of Belfast Lough just east of Carrickfergus, is our last coal-fired electricity generation plant and is due to close next year.Read MoreUkrainian refugee scheme: Vital that sponsors in Northern Ireland are properly checked, warns anti-slavery expertUp to £m of RHI money may go unspent by StormontHowever, it is still key to keeping the lights on, and has been called upon more in recent years due to problems at other power stations and unusually calm days reducing wind power generation.Coal was Russia’s third most valuable export by value in , bringing in £.bn. Northern Ireland was the only UK region to see coal-fired electricity generation increase that year, accounting for % of all electricity.Energy imports from Russia have not been banned, but have come under scrutiny due to revulsion at Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine and the escalation of the war through the targeting of civilians.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Kilroot’s position appears similar to that of Shell, which bought Russian oil — entirely legally — days into the Ukraine war, but backtracked under huge public pressure and promised not to do so again.Read MoreMalachi O#Doherty:OpinionMy utility bills now cost £ a week. Pensioners are in big troubleHowever, Kilroot’s situation is complicated by what it says is a requirement in its licence to buy Russian coal for environmental reasons, because it is low-sulphur, and thus somewhat reduces air pollution when burned.!forfort[r].style.e.data["datawrapper-height"][a]+"px"When Stormont’s Department for the Economy, which is responsible for electricity policy, was askedit believed environmental rules should be relaxed to allow Kilroot to burn dirtier coal, it initially washed its hands of the matter, saying: “The department does not have responsibility for environmental rules. This is the responsibility of DAERA Northern Ireland Environment Agency .”That answer came despite the RHI Inquiry recommending Stormont stopped operating in silos and behaved coherently as a single government entity.However, Kilroot’s owner then told the Belfastit had been meeting the department, NIEA, electricity grid operator SONI and the Utility Regulator to discuss this issue since the crisis began. That was put to the Department for the Economy and to Edwin Poots’ Department of Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairs, which is responsible for NIEA.But there was no response at the time of going to press.EP Kilroot, a subsidiary of Czech company Energetický, which owns the plant, said it “condemns the indefensible aggression and actions by Russia”.It added that it “complies with all UK sanctions and associated regulations in relation to Russia”, and stressed there were “signicant stock levels of coal on the Kilroot site at present”.It said: “We have contingency plans in place for alternative sources of coal supply. “This plan requires changing EP Kilroot’s permit, which currently prevents us from using coals from other countries.“Since the start of the Ukraine crisis, EP Kilroot has chaired a number of roundtable workshops with officials from DfE, NIEA, the Utility Regulator and SONI to urgently address the issues of the current permitting arrangements to enable EP Kilroot to remove its reliance on Russian coal.“If the permitting arrangements are not changed, we believe there will be signicant security of supply risks that SONI will need to manage.”The company claimed there could also be “signicant additional costs” for consumers “depending on the extent to which the coal units are restricted”.When DfE, headed by DUP minister Gordon Lyons, was asked for its view on whether Kilroot should continue to buy Russian coal, the department expressed no preference, and said: “The purchase of coal is a commercial decision taken by EP Kilroot. However, the department will follow the guidance that has been issued by the UK Government in relation to Russian imports.”When asked how much coal stocks were in place at Kilroot, DfE said “this is not a matter for the department”, but SONI would tell itthere was a problem. When asked how much secondary fuel was stored at Kilroot, DfE said that was a matter for the company.SONI said it was “unaware of any immediate risk to coal stock at Kilroot”. It said inspection of fuel stocks was “not a matter for SONI”. It added Kilroot “has a key role to play in the energy transition”, involving the current generators as well as new gas turbines.Belfast Harbour said it was “working closely with shipping agents and relevant partners to implement all of the Government’s legislative sanctions on Russian vessels”, but it would only bar vessels excluded by law, rather than go further.The Utility Regulator said Kilroot was responsible for ensuring it held adequate fuel stocks. It added: “In light of the ongoing situation in Ukraine, we are working with DfE to proactively monitor the situation, and are engaging with EP Kilroot and other key stakeholders on a regular basis about fuel stocks and fuel security arrangements.”Overall imports of coal have generally been falling, but have risen to the point where they are now roughly where they were in , despite the reduction in the use of coal for home-heating and electricity generation.Irish state-owned electricity company ESB said it will not be taking delivery of Russian coal to its Moneypoint power station in Co Clare “for the foreseeable future”. It was reported that members of staff at the River Shannon facility had expressed concerns to management about accepting Russian coal in the current circumstances.On Monday, Andrei Melnichenko, owner Credit: PacemakerAllan PrestonTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailWith St Patrick’s Day celebrations ing in style across Northern Ireland this week, the Belfasthas everything you need to know on travel arrangements and weather.The Met Office has forecast that Wednesday promises to be a dry day after a misty start to the morning, with sunny periods and light winds to follow.Maximum temperatures are expected to be °C.Read MoreSt Patrick’s Day : Events and activities across Northern Ireland this March Looking ahead to the main event on Thursday, those travelling to celebrations are told to expect bright spells and scattered showers before drier conditions later in the day.Friday and Saturday are forecast to be dry and mild with some good spells of sunshine.With huge numbers expected to attend St Patrick’s Day celebrations across Northern Ireland, Translink will be operating holiday timetables on Thursday, March .Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines Translink website by using the Journey Planner feature, or by phoning the Contact Centre for information on    .For the largest event in Belfast, the main celebrations start on Wednesday night with a free St Patrick’s concert taking place in Custom House Square between pm to pm.Belfast City Council have called on drivers to exercise extreme caution when driving in and around the area of Custom House Square, Queen’s Square and Victoria Street due to large volumes of pedestrians attending the event.Those attending should also not there is no designated city centre parking for the evening concert.Drivers are also advised not to park at the SSE Arena on Wednesday night due to the Challenge Cup Final ‘Belfast Giants v Cardf Devils’ taking place.For those wishing to drive, other car parks are available near Custom House Square including the NCP Belfast City Quays Car Park on Donegall Quay.On St Patrick’s day on Thursday, traffic restrictions and ersions will operate in Belfast City Centre during the annual Carnival Parade.Belfast City Council has encouraged those attending any of the events to use public transport.On street parking, including blue badge spaces, will be suspended from am to .pm along Upper Arthur Street, Donegall Place, High Street, Bridge Street and Donegall Street to accommodate the parade and spectators.Drivers can also expect some disruption along the parade route, with rolling ersions in place from .pm to .pm on roads and streets that intersect with the route.The pageant is to leave Belfast City Hall at pm and travel down Donegall Place, turning right into Castle Place, then High Street, left into Bridge Street, Waring Street and finishing on Donegall Street close to Writers Square.There will also be no designated city centre parking for the St Patrick’s carnival parade.Further information on city centre car parks is available here.Elsewhere in the city, drivers should note the SPAR Craic k event will see around , runners leaving Belfast directions of police, any signage and exercise caution along the route.Looking to events in Londonderry, those attending are also encouraged to use public transport where possible and drivers are told to expect some delays and ersions.Bishop Street, Shipquay Street and Strand Road will be restricted to traffic for ying s of time during the afternoon between pm and pm with ersions in place.The Foyle Credit: Liam McBurney PA WireSam McBrideTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailStormont is on course to waste at least £m — and perhaps as much as £m — over the next  years due to its failure to find a way to spend Treasury funding made available to Northern Ireland for subsidising renewable heat.As revealed by the Belfastlast week, £m has already been wasted in this way and there is no sign of the Department for the Economy producing an alternative proposal for how it can spend the money.However, new figures show the vast scale of the waste aheadthe situation remains unaltered. In response to a Freedom of Information request from the Renewable Heat Association— which represents most RHI claimants — the department said that it was now on course to underspend by around £m. However, those figures only cover expenditure until , yet the GB RHI scheme — from whose budget Northern Ireland’s share of money for renewable heat is derived — has been extended and will not now close until .Based on that longer duration for the GB scheme, RHANI has calculated that Northern Ireland’s underspend may be closer to £m.Read MoreCriticism as Queen’s University Belfast ‘spends over £k’ on Amazon during pandemicThe hidden RHI scandal of how Stormont wasted £m in green energy subsidiesThe department said that it “will explore the potential to utilise any available [Treasury] funds in support of alternative or additional actions to decarbonise heat”. However, there is still no suggestion that this work has reached an advanced stage nor even that it will be possible because the Executive remains unable to decide how to handle existing RHI claimants.Those claimants were promised unalterable payments for  years but once the calamitous scale of the RHI overspend became apparent, Stormont abandoned that promise and retrospectively slashed their payments, meaning the actual overspend was £.m.That decision made them far less well rewarded than their counterparts in Great Britain or the Republic of Ireland, which recently launched its own version of RHI — putting Northern Irish businesses at a competitive disadvantage.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Sources within the DUP suggest that the party is split on how to handle the situation. Former leader Arlene Foster — the minister who set up the disastrous scheme but then said she was “accountable but not responsible” for the mess which followed — had endorsed a policy of throwing all RHI claimants out of the scheme, paying them a fraction of what they were originally promised as compensation. Sinn Fein has also endorsed this policy, but other DUP figures believe it is unfair to those claimants who entered the scheme in good faith, took on huge loans at the suggestion of its minister and government officials, and who did not abuse RHI.There is another factor which might explain the decision not to spend such a vast sum of money. The retrospective cuts to subsidies which had been guaranteed were immediately challenged in court by claimants. However, that process has moved tortoise-like over the last five years and has not yet gone to the Supreme Court. That case is just one of several RHI legal actions, the outcome of which the department cannot be certain.It may be that its decision not to launch a new green heat scheme is a way of hedging against the possibility that the original scheme is reinstated and it faces a vast compensation bill.Whatever the reason, it is having an increasingly stark impact. As oil and gas prices soar, renewables are among the cheapest alternatives — but have high up-front costs to install, which is why subsidies are in place where across the UK and Ireland.RHANI executive chairman Andrew Trimble said: “If civil servants had not removed  words from the national legislation on renewable heat when the NI legislation was implemented, then today we would have a strong, sustainable, environmentally friendly renewable heat sector. We would be contributing to our pathway to net zero and have a vastly reduced reliance on fossil fuels — with their polluting emissions reduced by %.”He said that Stormont could solve the problem by reinstating the missing  words — essentially replicating the GB scheme, with cost controls, something he said “could solve the political problems that Stormont and the department have created for themselves and for the people of Northern Ireland”.Mr Trimble highlighted that in , a Commons committee inquiry branded the department’s actions “a raw deal”, but the department had repeatedly failed title: experts give contrasting views on sheerans shape of you at copyright trial
story: Ed Sheeran performs during the Brit Awards   FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueEd Sheeran performs during the Brit Awards  By Tom Pilgrim, PAMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailMusicology experts have given contrasting views at a High Court trial over whether Ed Sheeran’s hit Shape Of You has “signicant similarities” or is “distinctively dferent” from a song he is accused of ripping off.American forensic musicologist Anthony Ricigliano concluded in a report for alegal row that it was “objectively unlikely” that any similarities between the  track and the song Oh Why by Sami Chokri “result from copying”.But Christian Siddell, another musicologist, reported that he found melodic similarities were “so numerous and striking that the possibility of independent creation is… highly improbable”.Mr Sheeran and his co-writers, Snow Patrol’s John McDaid and producer Steven McCutcheon, deny that Shape Of You copies part of the  song by Mr Chokri – a grime artist who performs under the name Sami Switch.Mr Chokri and his co-writer Ross O’Donoghue claim that a central “Oh I” hook in Mr Sheeran and his co-authors’ track is “strikingly similar” to an “Oh Why” refrain in their own composition."data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk face .ece AUTOCROP h bpanews_a--ed-f-ceaccc_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk face .ece AUTOCROP h FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueSami Chokri Both musicology experts gave evidence on their analysis of the songs at an ongoing trial in London on Wednesday.In a joint written statement, they agreed that “when heard in the context of their respective works, the words ‘Oh why’ and ‘Oh I’ may be phonetically indistinguishable from each other to the casual listener”.They also agreed that neither of them had found “the same combination of either the ‘Oh Why’ phrase – combined phonetic sound plus pitch and rhythm – nor the ‘Oh I’ phrase – combined phonetic sound plus pitch and rhythm – in any other compositions”.Lawyers for Mr Chokri and Mr O’Donoghue allege that when the two songs’ melodies are transposed into the same key “the progression of notes is the same”.They also claim the rhythm of the tracks’ melodies are “almost identical”, their use of instrumentation “creates a strikingly similar sound and texture” and the vowel sounds in the chanted tune “further enhances the similarity”."data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk  .ece AUTOCROP h bpanews_a--ed-f-ceaccc_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk  .ece AUTOCROP h FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueSongwriter John McDaid Mr Ricigliano, who was instructed by the Shape Of You co-writers’ lawyers but told the court he was “completely impartial”, said in a report that he considered the extent of the alleged similarities between the two songs to be “overstated”.He wrote that “the overall design and musical development of the melodic, harmonic and lyrical content in the relevant phrase in Shape Of You are distinctively dferent from that utilised in Oh Why”.Mr Ricigliano added: “Such similarities as there are, when placed in context, in my view lack signicance in relation to the allegation of copying from Oh Why.“They are commonplace forms of expression, both in terms of use by other writers and by Mr Sheeran himself.“My view is therefore that it is objectively unlikely that any similarities result from copying.”In court, Andrew Sutclfe QC, representing Mr Chokri and Mr O’Donoghue, asked him: “You accept, don’t you Mr Ricigliano, that despite all your research you have not found any examples in any corner of the earth over the past  years which sound phonetically the same as the chorus in Oh Why and the post chorus in Shape Of You.”"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk f .ece AUTOCROP h bpanews_a--ed-f-ceaccc_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk f .ece AUTOCROP h FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueEd Sheeran outside the High Court “That’s correct,” Mr Ricigliano said.“Do you not find this extraordinary ” Mr Sutclfe asked, with the expert replying: “No”.The barrister described the two song phrases as appearing “within months of each other” and suggested they sound “almost the same”.“I would disagree with the characterisation,” Mr Ricigliano said, adding that the two are “coincidentally similar” and have “distinctive dferences”.Mr Sheeran has argued in his written evidence that his song’s Oh I phrase uses “a basic minor pentatonic pattern” which is “entirely commonplace”.In court, Mr Siddell, who was instructed by Mr Chokri and Mr O’Donoghue’s lawyers but outlined his own professional opinion in his report, said he felt there had been “over emphasis” in relation to references to the minor pentatonic scale in the case, adding: “The Oh I and Oh Why phrases are melodies not scales.”In his own report he concluded that there were “striking and substantial similarities between certain aspects of the lead vocal melody of Oh Why and Shape Of You”.He said the two melodies were “nearly identical in respect of their rhythm and pitch”, the phonetic sounds of the vocal lines were “musically indistinguishable to the ear” and other compositional similarities included the use of “phrase repetition” and “the musical dynamics”.Mr Siddell said that similarities between the two works were “unlikely to be the consequence of coincidence”.“From a solely musical perspective, I find the melodic similarities to be so numerous and striking that the possibility of independent creation is in my view highly improbable,” he said.He added: “Had I been consulted in a ‘ compliance’ capacity as to whether a licence should title: nazanin zaghari ratcliffe on flight out of iran as six year nightmare ends
story: Nazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe is on her way back to Britain  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueNazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe is on her way back to Britain By David Hughes, Gavin Cordon and Patrick Daly, PA Political StaffMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailNazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe’s six-year ordeal in Iran is over after she was released from detention and boarded a flight out of the country as the UK Government settled an outstanding £ million debt owed to the regime in Tehran.Her husband Richard Ratclfe, who has fought a tenacious battle to secure her release, said he was “deeply grateful” and that he and their daughter Gabriella were “looking forward to a new le”.The British-Iranian mother is ing to Britain, along with a second dual national, Anoosheh Ashoori.A third dual national, Morad Tahbaz, has been released from prison on furlough.Mrs Zaghari-Ratclfe was detained on security charges by the Iranian Revolutionary Guard at Imam Khomeini airport after a holiday visit to Iran where she introduced her daughter Gabriella to her parents.Mr Ashoori has been in prison for almost five years while Mr Tahbaz has been held for four.Their release follows months of intensive diplomatic negotiations between London and Tehran.Foreign Secretary Liz Truss said: “We have the deepest admiration for the resolve, courage and determination Nazanin, Anoosheh and Morad, and their families, have shown.“They have faced hardship that no family should ever experience and this is a moment of great relief.”Mr Ratclfe has long claimed that his we was being used as a pawn in a dispute between the UK and Iran over the unpaid debt linked to an arms dealThe UK has paid the £. million owed to Iran after it cancelled an order of Chieftain tanks following the overthrow of the Shah in the revolution of .In a statement, Ms Truss confirmed the debt had been settled “in parallel” with the release of the detainees.She said it had been done “in full compliance with UK and international sanctions and all legal obligations”.She added: “These funds will be ring-fenced solely for the purchase of humanitarian goods.”Sanctions on the Tehran regime had been one of the key sticking points in being able to settle the debt.Ms Zaghari-Ratclfe and Mr Ashoori were initially being take to the Gulf state of Oman – which has been closely involved in the behind-the-scenes negotiations to secure their release.Oman’s foreign minister Badr Albusaidi posted a picture of them arriving at the airport, adding: “Soon they will be with their loved ones at home.”Nazanin and Anoosheh have arrived safely in Oman. Sincere thanks for the hard work and good faith in Tehran and London that made this possible. Soon they will be with their loved ones at home. We hope this result will bring further progress in the dialogue between the parties. pic uqDQsgHC— Badr Albusaidi - بدر البوسعيديMarch , From there it is expected they will be flown on a Government-chartered flight to RAF Brize Norton in Oxfordshire.Boris Johnson, visiting Gulf states, welcomed news of the detainees’ release.“The UK has worked intensively to secure their release and I am delighted they will be reunited with their families and loved ones,” he tweeted.Mrs Zaghari-Ratclfe’s MP Tulip Siddiq, who has long campaigned for her release, posted a photograph of her on the flight carrying her to freedom.“It’s been six long years – and I can’t believe I can FINALLY share this photo. Nazanin is now in the air flying away from six years of hell in Iran,” she tweeted.Mr Ratclfe, campaigned tirelessly for her release including staging a hunger strike outside the Foreign Office.We can stop being a moment in history and start being a normal family againRichard RatclfeHe said: “We can stop being a moment in history and start being a normal family again.”He said his we had a “big grin” in the photo on the plane and “it is going to be lovely to see her, lovely to catch up with her”.Mr Ratclfe said he had been “kept out of the loop” on discussions about settling the arms debt, but “I’m relieved the problem has been solved”.He said his we had asked him to make her a cup of tea when she arrives in the UK.Speaking alongside Gabriella, he added: “I think actually we were looking at the house and it needs a bit of tidying, so there might be a bit of tidying, perhaps directed by mummy when she comes back.”"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph incoming be .ece AUTOCROP h bpanews_bff--b--abe_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph incoming be .ece AUTOCROP h bpanews_bff--b--abe_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeClose"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph incoming be .ece AUTOCROP h bpanews_bff--b--abe_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph incoming be .ece AUTOCROP h bpanews_bff--b--abe_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Richard Ratclfe with his daughter Gabriella outside his home ahead of his we Nazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe’sPA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueRichard Ratclfe with his daughter Gabriella outside his home ahead of his we Nazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe’sIn a  statement the family of Mr Ashoori said: “This day has been a long time coming, and we are thankful for the efforts of everyone involved in bringing Anoosheh home.“, days ago our family’s foundations were rocked when our father and husband was unjustly detained and taken away from us.
